text:
I do want to say that what
I love about our community is that I get to learn from
all of you in the process.

I'm going to make
this really informal, and I apologize in
advance if there's things that you've seen already.

I'm basically going
to tell a story that pieces together some
events from the last decade, maybe a little before, and then
talks about some work that's

going to be presented at CHI 25
and then hints at ongoing work.

So how many of you have ever
seen this or heard of the Sabre system for planning flights?

I can't see everyone's
faces, but I do see some people saying yes. Well, Sabre was conceived of
in 1953 and was built in 1960.

A collaboration between
American Airlines and IBM, it pioneered airline
travel basically

around buying and
selling travel services. So prior to that, reservations
were primarily managed on paper.

And the average reservation
required about 90 minutes. So the new system managed the
equivalent of 83,000 phone calls

a day. And in '76, it was
offered to travel agents. And 1982 study found
that agents were choosing

the top retuned
selection on the Sabre site more than half the time,
and flights on the first page

more than 92% of the time. So a ranking
algorithm had evolved, and the design was intentional.

Internally, they called this
manipulation screen science. It was a bit subtle
at first and got bolder and bolder
as more expensive

American flights appeared first
before cheaper and shorter flights from competitors.

And then complaints from
competitors and travel agents led the US Civil
Aeronautics Board

and the Department of Justice to
launch antitrust investigations. Speaking to US Congress in 1983,
Robert Crandall, the CEO, said,

"The preferential display of our
flights and the corresponding increase in our market
share is the competitive,"

I'm going to mispronounce this. I'll just say, "raison
for having created Sabre in the first place."

And as a result of
this, in '84, the board decreed that the sorting
algorithms for Sabre

must be known. And they passed a
little known regulation called the Display
of Information,

requiring, among
other provisions, that each airline reservation
system shall provide to any person upon request the
current criteria used in editing

and ordering flights for
the integrated displays and the weight given to each
criterion and the specifications

used by the systems programmers
in constructing the algorithm. It was a challenging
mailing process.

It's not clear that the
responses made sense to consumers, but they made
this uncovering regulation.

Today this algorithm
manipulation is, again, a pressing
societal concern and, as you've likely seen in
the press, way beyond airlines.

And so as Michael mentioned,
inspired by this case and federal and
state civil rights

laws, in 2014, we introduced
the concept of algorithm audits

because transactions involving
core social goods covered by our laws were increasingly
taking place online.

And in our paper, we
talked about four areas. But I'm going to give an
example, just with fair housing

up front for in the
interest of time. So why would we audit
a housing system?

And how? And what are the
questions we would ask? And one of the questions
we were curious about was,

are racial minorities
less likely to find housing via algorithmic
matching systems? And I mentioned we were
inspired by civil rights laws.

So there's a Fair Housing
Act of 1968 and the Housing and Community
Development Act of 1987,

which further supported
special projects, including the development of
prototypes to respond to new or sophisticated
forms of discrimination

against persons protected. And so many of you
may not know this,

but HUD routinely
performs housing audits. HUD being the Department of
Housing and Urban Development.

And in a traditional housing
audit, what they would do is they would make
family pairs that

are matched on everything except
for one protected category. And then they would have
these families successfully

visit realtors, and
then the researchers would control and
isolate discrimination. And the first of these pair
tests happened in 1977.

And the most recent one
I could find was in 2012.

And in this one, Blacks were
shown about 17.7% fewer homes than whites.

Asians were shown about 18.8%
fewer homes than whites. And note that these
audits roughly take place

around every decade or so. And they are very costly. And they require a lot of time
and collecting of families.

So let's move online now. Imagine a website
that lists homes that could similar
discrimination be happening

here? So for example, here,
I see these homes. So why is one home
listed up front?

And why is another
home listed at the end? And these high prices, by
the way, are from 2018.

Also troubling, at the bottom,
if you look at that label, it says "safe neighborhoods." That label can actually cause
interesting side effects.

So one being the reinforcement
of certain stereotypes. But also what makes
something safe, what

makes this label, who puts on
this value system to people? And so what we did is we
mimicked mimics directly

these traditional
social science audits, but we did that
with sock puppets. So we decided to find out what
happens on these websites.

And so these sock puppets are
basically unique fake identities online that directly mimic the
traditional audits that we just

discussed. And so we created thousands
of identities or agents, as you see on the left.

We had white female, white
male, Black female, Black male, Hispanic female, Hispanic
male, Asian female, Asian male.

And each agent starts as
a fresh browser profile with no cookies or history. It browses the internet
following specific patterns.

More specifically, each category
of sock puppet browsing sites are disproportionately
visited by members of their specific
demographic group

to build this
representative profile. And we use statistics on
gender, age, income, ethnicity,

and education to
create these profiles. And similar traditional
audits, the profiles represent prospective
home buyers

who differ in gender
and race but are similar in location and income. And we had blocks of
training and collection

that we scheduled throughout
the week at varying times. And then we trained the
profiles to visit target sites

and collect experimental
data for analysis. In our first audit,
we explored rankings.

So the order that
things appeared. And we found that women's feeds
contained more expensive homes

at the top compared
to men's feeds. We also conducted a
second housing audit.

Less known is that it also is
illegal to advertise around

real estate and discriminate in
this advertise-- discriminate in this advertisement.

So we did an audit around
the ads presented to people. To put this law into context
and how it came to be,

The New York Times was sued
in 1991, Ragin versus New York Times. Basically, The
Sunday Times featured

thousands of human models
of whom virtually none were Black in their home section. The white models depicted
potential homeowners or renters.

But the Black models
depicted typically maintenance employees,
doormen, small children, or cartoon characters.

And the argument was that the
repeated and continued depiction of white human models
and the virtual absence

of a Black human models
depicted a preference on the basis of race. The case went on
for four-plus years.

Eventually, The New York
Times settled and adopted a policy accepting
residential real estate

advertising that reflected the
metropolitan area's population. In our audit, we used
the same approach

that we used for the rankings. We collected all
the advertisements presented to our sock puppets. And of the job ads, we found
that sock puppets representing

white people saw more housing
ads than non-white sock puppets and the sock puppets
representing Black people saw

more ads for rent to own
ads than non-white puppets, a category of ads that are
notorious for being predatory.

Now, in this work and in
crafting these audits, we are building on
work of many others, such as Batya Friedman,
Helen Nissenbaum, who

stated that freedom from
bias should be counted among the select
set of criteria, including reliability,
accuracy, efficiency,

according to which the quality
of systems in use in society should be judged. Also inspired by the
politics of search

by Introna and Nissenbaum. And that led to many, many of
our audits, of which I've mapped

only a subset of them here. And as you notice,
they span this gamut

of talking to people
and computing. And this housing audit
that I just described falls on the right
end of the spectrum.

Methods involving people on
the-- and methods involving people are on the left. And the style of
audit is important.

It illustrates why
in the sense that we can monitor more continuously.

And we can see
things longer term. But we also have to care about
these audits on the left.

but it's important
to state and just to see the frequency
in which this happens. These are important because as
you might recall, in October

2016, it was found that
Facebook allowed advertisers to exclude users by race.

Addressing these concerns
because they did not want further-- they claimed they did not
want to further support

historical oppression,
they publicly stated that they would
put an end to this. In February 27, they
said specifically

that they would stop
this, particularly in the areas of housing,
employment, and credit.

However, November
2017, ProPublica found that they're
still excluding by race.

Then in 2018, they promised
that they would bar advertisers from targeting by
race or ethnicity.

But then later that
year, they were found of gender
discrimination in job ads.

They then said they
were going to do more to protect against
discrimination in housing. This is March of '19.

And yet, you can still
in 2019 discriminate against women, older workers,
despite the civil rights

settlement. And it was so easy
to get these ads. And ProPublica got their
ads in roughly like-- an

under 15 minutes. You can still find
discrimination through image selection by job
advertisers on Facebook when

they post jobs, for
example, for nurses and you see primarily females. And look, this is clearly a
hard problem, especially when

machine learning is involved. But it's because it is such a
hard and opaque problem that we need these audits.

And if it weren't
for these audits, we would not know
what was going on. And housing and similar
audits fill a need.

And we were excited that under
the Obama administration, they mentioned
these audits as one

of five national priorities
essential for the development of big data technologies. And they specifically
said that we

need to promote academic
research and industry development of
algorithmic auditing and external testing
of big data systems

to ensure that people
are being treated fairly. And I have been
very excited to see

that the number of people
discussing audits academically is increasing.

And this graph on the bottom
is just from Google Scholar, not counting all
the amazing work being done by investigative
journalists and others.

And we're seeing these
topics discussed, in fact, in ICA and CSCW and
NeurIPS, CHI, and more.

But I should note that
these do require care oversight and systems change. We need careful scrubbing of
data, sanity checks on data.

And I mentioned
this housing audit. One benefit of
that style of audit is that we can monitor
systems frequently,

but we also need to
make sure that we can make sense of this data. And it's important that we
think about how to craft audits.

And crafting them is
not without challenges. As an example, an arrest
in recidivism audit that we were conducting,
we found data

to be unreliable to the
different data entry tools that were used and the
interfaces that were used. For example, in one state, it
claimed that 99% of the crimes

happened in just one city. And it just so
happened that city was at the top of a pulldown menu.

But I want to highlight
another form of audit that receives less attention
gravitas, as we move left on this axis.

And that's a narrative
visualization audit that we did that was
led by Motahhare Eslami.

And in this audit, we included
data with your permission so you understood how
relationships emerged.
But it required an interview. And it was very, very extensive.

There were actually
two parts to this. One was interview. One, you could do on your own. But I'm going to talk about
the interview part first

and how we got to it. We were interested in seeing how
people made sense of their news feeds, in a sense, how they
could figure out what to tune in

and what approaches they used to
get the content or the reception that they wanted. So some of you may
remember antennas.

There were things we
attached to television sets. And we moved them
around to get reception.

I remember having my dad on the
roof and me in the basement, yelling at him when we could see
the soccer game on the screen.

But how do you get the reception
that you want on Facebook? We made one mistake up front.

We assumed that people knew
their feed was curated. But we discovered, again, and
we're discovering even today

that not everyone knows that
their feeds are curated. In fact, an award-winning
doctor at Harvard replied, why would
they even do that,

when we explained
our study to them. So awareness was
becoming and continues to be a big theme of our work.

And in that early study, we
found that roughly 62% of people were not aware that there was a
algorithm curating their feeds.

That study was replicated in
2017 with a similar result, and we found that people
were blaming themselves.

"I bet it would be on my feed. I would catch it at some
point during the day." And, "I didn't
scroll down enough.

If I'd scroll down, I
would have found it." So let me just briefly explain
what this interface was.

I called it a narrative
visualization. On the image on the
left, what you're seeing are posts that were sent by
everybody in your network.

And highlighted in blue
are the ones that you saw. On the right, you're seeing
the post that you did see. And so at first glance,
for most of the people,

this is when they realized that
there was an algorithm curating their feed. They were seeing roughly 30%.

in the middle, people that see
roughly half of your posts; and on the right, people
who see all of your posts.

And again, this was a
shock for some people. And one person became
extremely angry when they realized they saw none
of the posts of their brother.

One of my favorite
quotes of this study was this one, like, "It's
kind of intense because have you seen the movie The Matrix?

It's kind of waking up
in the matrix in a way. I mean, you have what you think
is your reality of what they

choose to show you." So awareness and
surprise was consistent.

And several expressions around
helplessness and loss of control emerged. We later asked people, though,
to, OK, this was rarely seen.

Would you move it
into another category? Or you did not see this post. Would you have wanted to see it? And they're like,
well, honestly,

there's not much
I need to change. It's not so bad. And they started to see
why the algorithm might

be helpful to them. They said things like, a
lot of what is filtered are things that
don't pertain to me. Otherwise, if they
didn't do this,

everything would be
really, really cluttered. We actually followed
up with them later. And we found that 80% of the
people who used our narrative

visualization became more
satisfied with their algorithmic system overall and described
that they were now "manipulating

the manipulation." But while we weren't
originally planning to do this, we also found that people
were telling us folk theories,

meaning nonauthoritative
conceptions of the world that develop
among nonprofessionals and circulate informally.

And we find that these folk
theories empowered them. They used them to
plan their behavior. I'm not going to go
into all of them.

I'm just going to
talk about two of them because that would be a
whole other four-hour talk. But one of them was the
personal engagement theory.

Here, for example,
one Facebook user thought that they
could always click like on one of their own
comments or status updates

and this would trigger
Facebook to show their post to more people. And one example, people
were trying to go

to people's websites and
say, if I click on that person's website, I will see--
on there on that person's--

I'm sorry, Facebook site, I
would see more of their posts. And people were also
making these strategies

for how it worked. They're like, OK, I keep liking
their baby photos because I feel I have to them, but I
don't want to see them anymore.

So now I'm going to hide
them, hoping that undoes the weight of the liking. So it was really interesting
to see how people

were thinking about this. The second theory
that came up a lot was the control panel theory.

People felt that this
gave them agency. And we were not the first to
come up with this control panel. folk theory.

Kempton, a research
studying thermostats, discovered this in the '60s. He discovered a coexistence
specifically of folk theories

in his work and
institutional theories. And he found that
each embraced theories

for-- each of these
theories that people came up with produced both efficiencies
and inefficiencies, to the point

that perhaps having a theory was
more useful than being correct. And we found that
in social media. So I'm going to go back to the
ideas of control agency in a bit

because it turned out to be
more important and much more complicated than we thought. But I wanted to highlight
that this type of audit

that actually veers toward the
left became really popular. It was used by thousands
of people internationally.

It was used in CS departments,
high schools, art design departments. Facebook requested the code.

We were told that
internally, it influenced how they evaluated their feeds. And when the API was deprecated,
people became really upset.

And we got hate mail when we
couldn't provide this anymore to them. People appreciate the element
of discovery and empowerment

in the tool. And the audit was twofold. I mentioned the
interview part of it. But it could be independent.

And people were
using it on their own and checking their
feeds over time and making decisions
based on that.

I do also want to note
that this style of audit requires more time, not
only to conduct the audit,

but also to design it. It took significantly longer
than the housing audit I described earlier.

However, it also provided
a level of insight about people and
their mental state that we could not get from
audits at the far right

of our spectrum. And we did not
expect the reactions we received around autonomy. Autonomy and awareness
became central themes

in a lot of our algorithmic
sociotechnical systems. And I don't believe that
autonomy and awareness

get the attention they deserve. I'm not going to delve too
much into this because I also

want to leave some
time for questions. And so I just briefly
want to mention that as we moved
across the spectrum,

we also discovered forms
of collective responses that inspired many of
our collective audits.

So, for example, in one study
around hotel aggregator systems, people were posting,
this is crazy,

this doesn't make any sense. They were giving us
ideas, and they actually helped us conceive of the
idea of the collective audit.

And Motahhare
Eslami, who did a lot of this work, the bulk
of it, I would say,

is now working on this
really cool project called WeAudit, getting
people to come together,

inspired by a lot
of this hotel work, where she found that
specifically, one aggregator site was rating their
low to medium quality

hotels 37% higher than other
hotel rating platforms.

And the comments from the people
were really nuanced and really, really insightful.

In fact, many of
them were saying, I looked at the algorithm. Even if I give everything is 0.

I cannot get anything
lower than a 2.5. They were then
re-appropriating the website to make their own rating system.

And the collective audit work,
I'm really excited about. And we're also seeing
people want to use our tools

and give feedback and
participate in the process themselves and
become the auditors.

And we're working also with
local community organizations via our Center for
Just Infrastructures and our community data
clinic to help, especially

with community-centered
audits that people want to do around
some technologies that actually affect our city and
affect the people of the city.

And I mentioned moving
across the access. But we need to be able to have
these broad backgrounds to be

able to move across
this access and conduct audits, such as the three
that I've talked about very briefly right now.

It requires a level
of multidisciplinarity that is not the norm. Creating and verifying systems
that audit dynamically,

changing processes
with distributed data-- with often distributed data. And dynamic data is complex.

Designing these visualizations. The design, the statistics,
and the legal practice

required to help guide us
is super, super important and takes significantly longer. So I've shared
three audits so far,

each of them
sociotechnical systems-- of sociotechnical systems. They do not exist in a vacuum.

And we are assessing
systems with people that are not always rational. And errors occur.

An example of the
farthest right might be an audit that stressed
fair allocation of resources with bounds and new
expert definitions.

Now, I'm not saying
that we shouldn't be doing theoretical audits
because they are important, but I'm finding that
we've had more impact when

we look at measurement
that responds to the real world
with real individuals.

Alternately, with
the far left, we have concerns around
bins for people. Our audits that only
look at males and females

are not accurate. There are things that
we should be looking at. And we should be looking
at intersectionality.

And we need to create
audits that can do that. So none of these are perfect. And it'd be wonderful if our
current laws and policies

were framed around some of
these bins that we are using. But we are doing our best
with the laws that we have

and trying to effect
change at the same time. And over the years,
I've had the privilege

of working with lawyers,
policy experts, sociologists. And we're trying to bring them
in at the beginning of our work

because that makes for just
much stronger work, especially because all technology
are once technical.

But they're also always
social, whether it be economic, cultural, or ideological.

And Michael briefly
mentioned a lawsuit. We did encounter
challenges with the methods

that we use to do our work,
specifically on the methods that we use to collect
our data, like the web

scraping and the sock puppets. And courts and federal
prosecutors at the time had interpreted the
law to make it a crime

to visit a website in a manner
that violated terms of service. We did not want to be criminals. We believe that this information
was important to the public.

And at least with
the housing audits, the Federal Housing Act
supported and, in theory, enforced the style of work.

So it did cause
fear and concern. In many cases, it chilled
and it closed research areas that we believe should
have been explored.

And it was a unique
trajectory, research wise, to actually file the suit.

And it was bumpy. But we did find some
protection for us and others in conducting audits.

We also have a forthcoming
book about this of the lawyer, journalist, sociologist, and
computer scientist, one of whom

was a graduate of
Stanford, Danae Metaxa. And so we feel a
little safer right now.

And the federal court ruled that
big data discrimination studies do not violate federal
antihacking laws.

The work was also covered
in the Bill of Rights-- the blueprint, rather,
for an AI Bill of Rights.

And Department of Justice
announced that specifically,

they would not
prosecute people who create fictional
accounts for hiring, housing, or rental
websites using pseudonyms

on social networking
sites that prohibit them or in violation of access
restrictions in terms of--

for terms of service. Wish they'd gone deeper,
but we feel a bit safer

now as we conduct these audits. And there are folks
actually calling for more controls
around these AI risks

that society's response,
despite promising first steps, is incommensurate
with the possibility

of rapid, transformative
progress that is expected by many experts. They say that AI
safety research.

Is lagging. President governance
initiatives lack the mechanisms and institutions to prevent
misuse and recklessness

and barely address
autonomous systems. And there's more
work to be done here.

There are plenty of people who
want audits right now, including governments,
communities, legislators.

So we need people and
approaches to do that. And there were some people
who used to want them,

like Mark Zuckerberg,
where they had originally called for regulation,
specifically

around harmful content,
election protection, and third, privacy and
data protection issues

and data portability, the last
one being quite self-serving. And there are people that are
saying, Americans specifically,

that social media companies from
this poll that have too much control over us and
the news that we see.

And while I've shown you an
example, at least one example of personalization helping, it's
not clear when that is the case

and if it is always the case. And moreover, people
have expressed feeling manipulated by these systems.

So we were curious and excited
by some of our earlier audit interventions when
folks expressed

that they were basically
manipulating the manipulation.

They felt some
empowerment over them. And they also stated
that the control settings were one of the main
levers that they had.

So we decided that it
was important for us to actually investigate these
control settings a bit more because they are everywhere.

Most major platforms
have a place where you can access
a large control panel. And whether it be
buried, maybe you

can steer the
algorithm a little. And platforms love
to tout how much control they're giving users.

Facebook has these
press releases frequently where they go, look,
we just added more settings. We were like, are these
settings actually succeeding

at supporting user autonomy? So we had some
experience in auditing.

So we're like, let's
check this out. So we also were getting
more and more complaints

from people about
algorithmically controlled settings that sometimes expired,
like in our feedback study

that I showed earlier with the
columns of people where you saw and didn't see, people would
sometimes snooze somebody

for 30 days and forget, that
maybe that's why they weren't seeing their posts. We're also seeing more and
more machine learning-backed

settings, where you could
click on top stories, where it can be really hard
for users to validate

whether their control
settings are actually working. And these are popping
up everywhere,

including X, Instagram,
Facebook, TikTok. The idea being to
increase user satisfaction

and to increase users' feelings
of control with these settings. But also as a general
feedback mechanism,

they claim to increase
user engagement. However, it's not
clear that people can accomplish goals with these
settings, let alone find them.

And we discovered
this as we were trying to find
out whether people were aware of these
settings and whether they

could navigate them. And so just as a highlight of
this navigation and awareness

study, we brought people
into in-lab interviews and had this survey
that we guided them

through as we sat next to them. And we asked them
questions, for example, like on the desktop
version of Facebook,

do you think a setting
or group of settings exists to block a particular
Facebook user from sending event invites to you?

It turns out there
is such a setting. We asked about 24 real control
settings like this example

and 11 made up ones. And we found that
50% of participants performed no better than
chance at identifying

which control settings existed. And this included some
users thought that settings existed that did not exist--

I'm sorry, who thought that
real settings did not exist; and users who thought that
made up ones did exist.

And we also in-lab
component, for more detail,

we asked people to complete six
tasks that could be accomplished with the control settings. For example, imagine you
wanted to make a close friend

always appear
first or prioritize in your homepage newsfeed. Prioritize a friend for
your feed right now.

And so we had them
walk us through it. And all participants struggled
to find the control setting

for at least one task. But when we later guided
them through the settings, 94% of participants wanted to
change at least one control

setting. So there's a desire for
control, but an inability to operationalize that desire,
possibly because of design.

And so I mentioned that 94%
of people change at least one setting. We thought it was interesting
that while people generally

thought ad settings did
not exist, in the survey, 80% of participants in
the follow-up walk-through

changed at least one ad
setting in the guided tour. And only one out
of over 30 people

managed to figure out how to
delete a Facebook account. Nobody else could.

And so we were finding
that on top of this, users were actually
misinterpreting settings.

Participants' reasons
for using settings did not quite match what
the settings actually did.

And notably, the settings
did neither of the things that you're seeing
on this slide. And this finding was
a little uncomfortable

because here you
have settings which are purported to provide people
a way to express autonomy. But Facebook was not doing
a good job of informing

people how the settings worked. So people were using the
settings for the wrong reasons. And we delved into
the literature.

And we could not find
much around settings. We found two books by
Jef Raskin, a Humane--

found two books,
one by Jef Raskin called The Humane Interface,
and then a Lewis and Rieman book on Task-Centered User
Interface Design.

We found a lot of work
around like factory equipment and settings and configurations.

And the work that
I just showed you that was the work by
[INAUDIBLE] is now in Ben Shneiderman's
recent Human-Centered AI

book that came about a short
while ago to address issues around control and AI.

And from this work, we
documented a plethora of settings on
social media sites that were popping up on more
than one location, not always

centralized. And they were confusing. And we were wondering, like,
could these act as a placebo?

And that got us
to question like, are we having an
illusion of control rather than control itself?

And so Kristen Vaccaro
crafted this study where she made her own
Twitter client at the time

and made these machine
learning-backed control settings. And this one, what you see
is one around popularity.

She also had ones around
sentiment, closeness, frequency. And what she did is she had
people participate in the study

where they had no
control settings, where they had a
controlled setting that

worked to the best
of our ability, and where you had control
setting that just presented you with random tweets.

And what she found was that
users were more satisfied with their news feeds when
control settings were present--

so the two settings on the left,
whether they were functioning or malfunctioning-- and that
people that had no setting

were much more upset and
that really was there was no statistically
distinguishable difference

between the functioning controls
and the malfunctioning control settings. And this is a problem
because people

can expect critical consequences
from these settings. And the FTC levied a
record-breaking $5 billion

fine on Facebook because
they had privacy control settings that were not operating
the way they were labeled.

Kristen brought people
back into the lab and followed this with a lab
experiment, this time showing

them the two feeds,
the malfunctioning one and the functioning
one, side by side. So the deception study.

She told them
that, look, we want to see which
algorithm is better. And users engaged with
the control settings.

And they played with them. And again, we found
that when something

didn't work the
way they expected, people made excuses
and blamed themselves. We thought everybody
would figure this out.

Instead, we found that they took
responsibility for it and said, no, it was me.

And they blamed themselves
when these expectations were violated.

One participant,
for example, said that the combinations of
controls that they set

created a situation that
was just implausible, and they should
never have done that.

Another person said that,
well, if I knew sports, I would have known who
this is but I don't. Another thing that we
found was that people

were creating controls of their
own, either by scrolling quickly or by using different platforms
to separate different users.

And now the results
converged for online and the in-lab studies. But we were concerned like, what
if our functioning control sets

were so terrible that they
were no different from random? And we finally-- because
it was a deception study,

we disclosed this at the end. And it turns out
that I think only two people, after we told
them that it was fake,

could find the fake one-- I'm sorry, only two people-- let me get this right
because this was a while ago.

Of everybody, when we
told them, two people actually figured it out.

And so it turns out that the
algorithms that we had created weren't that bad.

And it was, again, a
little bit troubling, but it also makes us take a more
critical eye at these settings.

So for example, there may be
financial motives behind them. We don't want to be that
naive and say that, look, they're just
designing bad studies.

That design is bad. There are motives behind this. Now sometimes users and
platforms' incentives align.

And they do help us get
more of what we want, but sometimes they don't. And this could explain
the rise in controls

that only pay lip service, like
cookie banners that still track you when they say no, or
the misleading privacy

settings mentioned earlier,
where restricting data sharing to friends only still
shared information

with third-party apps. Now, this took me aback
a little bit further. It got me reflecting on a
tool that Eric Gilbert built.

He is now a professor
at Michigan. It was called We Meddle. He built this in 2010. And in this
interface, users chose

which algorithms they
wanted to use in their feed. So on the right, you've got
like sentiment, frequency.

And the reason I brought
this into this talk today was because it made me think
that this was so quaint.

It never even occurred
to us at that time to change the

of view like our purview.

We filtered out some things. For example, if you wanted

But it didn't occur to us that
let's just change the order. And I don't know if
that was us being naive or it was a different way of
thinking about engagement.

I would welcome what you think
about this after the talk. I also wanted to mention
that this feedback was

used internationally. This one, I think, was used
by over 100,000 people. And it actually-- I
remember one night

Eric was running to the lab. And he's like, OK, we got to
become experts in distributed computing because the site is
crashing because so many people

are using it. It also got me to
reflecting on how

do you know that a setting
is supporting autonomy. We've already shown that
users judges setting

to be useful because it
has a placebo effect, but people may feel autonomy
but not actually have it.

And so we decided that
replication is important. We wanted to replicate
Kristen's study, but this time at a larger scale.

So we ran a probability
sample across the US using the NORC system,
which is like AmeriSpeak.

So we dug deeper, created
another version of the placebo experiment. This time, we tried to
tease apart certain things,

trying better to
explain the how. So you have a control setting. And you have feed satisfaction.

But what got us to it? And we had four mechanisms that
we assessed-- expectations,

sovereignty, clicking,
and randomness. And I'll get to
these more in a bit.

But each of these mechanisms
makes a distinct prediction about the outcomes
of the experiment. And our strategy was to attempt
to falsify the predictions made

by each mechanism. So if a prediction
did not come true, it provides strong evidence
to rule out the mechanism.

So how did we do this? We were using a Bayesian
analysis and causal inference.

And we were making these DAGs. So the expectations
mechanism basically predicts that there's a
confirmation bias that

gives people a feeling of
control or satisfaction, meaning that the
mechanism a user

thinks the setting will work. This causes confirmation bias
towards the feed after the use--

after using the setting. And people easily find
evidence to convince themselves

that the setting has worked as
intended, as we've already seen. And this could explain
participants' behavior in their prior work.

More concretely, this
mechanism predicts that people will
use the setting, experience greater feelings of
control and feed satisfaction.

So why this prediction? So recall that the
key to this mechanism is confirmation bias towards
changes in the feeling--

in the feed being good. So if you've ever used a
setting or change the feed, if you don't use this, there's
no changes to be biased about.

And so second possible
mechanism that we looked at was the sovereignty mechanism.
Let me just go here. So here you have a slider. You use the slider. You have a feeling of control. You get to feed satisfaction.

And the slider is down below. In the sovereignty
mechanism, it predicts

that the knowledge
that one has control feels good, even if
you don't use it.

So this posits that
people feel in control and are satisfied
because of the fact that they see a setting
in the interface.

They take comfort in the fact
that they could potentially take control or
have sovereignty. This also implies that even
if you don't use a setting,

you will feel more in control
and satisfied with the feed. The third mechanism is
the clicking mechanism.

I'm the type of person
that I will just keep typing LS or
DIR in a box, just because it makes me feel good.

What if people like
to click and do things just because it makes
you feel productive?

And so the third
proposed mechanism is this clicking--
that this proposes that users have subconsciously
associated the action

of clicking with satisfaction. It even happens when
they consciously know they aren't meaningfully
controlling anything.

And so we also have
another version of this that we
put on top of it. To have an extra test
for this mechanism,

we added a fourth
experimental condition where participants saw a button
that just swapped two tweets. It didn't give you anything.

It just swapped tweets. Just to have you click to
see if the outcome mattered.

And the last mechanism was
the-- the last mechanism was the randomness mechanism. That randomness is satisfying.

For example, you see more
diverse, unexpected content. And this proposes that something
about the randomness of itself

is satisfying to people. Maybe randomness is surfacing
more diverse and unexpected content and people like that.

Notably, this mechanism proposes
it's not about the placebo effects or having
control at all,

but it's about
the pure objective quality of the feed content. And so you see these
predictions here.

Some people are assigned
to the randomness feed with no setting at all. So we wanted to get a sense.

We just wanted to
cover all of our bases. And so just to recap,
it's really useful

to know when a
setting is useful. So we looked at several
different mechanisms.

And so we designed
this experience to explore how the
placebo effects might

be resulting in some of this. So we put users in an
experimental condition

where they saw the Twitter
feed and were assigned to one of these five
different interfaces that

have or did not have settings. And then we tried to
model all of the arrows. And what did we find?

When we ran the numbers,
most of the paths did not display
significant effects. That is, the predictions
of randomness, clicking,

and the sovereignty
hypothesis did not come true. So this provided strong evidence
to rule these mechanisms out.

We did, however, find a positive
effect of control settings and feed selection.

And the bulk of this evidence
happened through the path in the middle, which
corresponds to the expectations

hypothesis, the very first
one that I explained. However, this effect size
was really small, smaller

than the first study
that we conducted. We get an average boost in
satisfaction of 0.13 points.

So what does this tell us? That we should still be aware
of placebo effects as users. That for designers,
the placebo effects

are smaller than
previously thought. But misleading people
also does not help. And for experimenters,
you really

need to separate the placebo
and the nonplacebo effects. And that's something
that people have not been doing in studies for control.

And we need to do more of it. And this experiment
demonstrates further one of the contributions of
methodology in a way of thinking

that can help with that. And expectations mechanisms
need further study.

And one of the
things we also found that-- so we need more measures. We need to interrogate
degrees of confirmation bias.

And also placebo effect
is really the wrong name. We should be using possibly
like expectations effect or confirmation bias effect.

And so I just also want
to say that we never proved that this
happens, but we did not rule out that expectation
mechanism happens.

There was so much
more to explore here. To dig a bit deeper,
we wanted to explore the offering of choice.

So we crafted a study
where we gave people-- that could give us
empirical evidence that could inform this debate.

So we ask, when users have
the option of control, are they more satisfied because
they adjusted the system

to behave better for them? Notably, despite the

give users more control,

these experiments seldom
separate the behavior from the option of choice.

And so basically, we looked
at systems that automatically provide and give
users what they want

versus giving them more
controls and choices. And we did this in the
context of choosing when to see an ad on YouTube.

So basically, you could see
a preroll ad, a midroll ad, or a choice between the two.

And the setup had
several advantages. First, the context
is significant.

Many people have
experienced this. More importantly, that there
are only two system behaviors.

Because it turns
out, in a prestudy, almost nobody
chose a midroll ad. So if people were shown
a preroll ad or chose it,

we could see if it was the
automatic system giving it to them that they preferred
or if it was their choice. So we got really,
really lucky here.

We didn't know that it
was going to happen. And so what did we find?

To recap, we found
that people preferred to get what they
wanted automatically more than the choice
over the ad placement.

Knows that-- I phrase
this as a comparison and that the choice
had no effect at all.

Small effects and choice
are still possible, and we would need
more statistical power to detect them-- or rather, I don't want to say
the choice had no effect at all,

but that the statistical power
was too small to detect it. Another finding was that
people expressed strong dislike

for forced choice. I also should note that this
is a very low stakes scenario.

If you see an ad
in the wrong time, it's not the end of the world. It's unlikely to cause
significant harm. But it's also important to
note that control can do more

than correct system behavior. It can show you transparency. And so it is important
to look at these to get a sense of what
your folk theories might

be as you use these systems. And like in the
previous study, I want to stress today that it's
really important to separate

choice from other behaviors
and to provide frameworks for doing this and that
these frameworks also

provide nuanced results. And that is OK because

or solidly on the other. And we really need-- it reminded

must turn over control
of tasks to computers, but users must never
feel out of control.

I'm going to go quickly now,

another form of control

that we've studied. And Kristen Vaccaro

model predictions. And few systems are
designed for contestability.

In fact, since this is a
new approach, an effort to increase interest,

And we're excited that when

This also led to work around

And nine workshops
grew out of this study where people shared
how they would design a system that stressed
control and contestability.

I don't want to-- I'm not going to go into
these details too much, but nine of these
workshops were with members from three marginalized
communities on Instagram

that had their content removed. And many of them needed
Instagram for their livelihood. Each group was
given a case study

that featured an experience

with content moderation.

And a lot of-- an example was

who got to define decency. And a lot of what

representation.

They wanted to be validated
by their peers, argumentation, cultural competence,

And some of these policies were
then overhauled by Facebook.
